mods:mods.mods:abstract: John Jay is confining himself to general remarks because of his lack of detailed knowledge of the matter at hand. It can rarely be proved, except by the man to whom it was offered, that a bribe has been made. If this man is disqualified by being interested in the penalty from giving testimony, the offender must be acquitted. There may also be other parts of the statutes in question which maybe found wanting. Washington might also indicate his unwillingness to increase revenue except to pay off the public debt. If there is a surplus of revenue this year, Jay thinks it might be used to pay off the debt to France. On the subject of Indian affairs Jay's information is too limited for him to see things as they are. If Washington intends to say anything of the territories under the government of the United States, he might recommend that schools be encouraged there and that highways be built to facilitate communication with adjacent states. Jay does not think anything can be said of foreign affairs unless something of great import to the United States occurs in the near future. It is Jay's opinion that it would be best to be silent on the question of a British minister to the United States. The judicial system needs reform, but that matter might be best discussed with the other subjects already mentioned rather than as a separate topic. Jay is also of the opinion that Washington should stress the necessity of keeping public and private communication separate. The census is another question of public interest. Jay is sorry to hear of the illness of Washington's nephew. There is no reason Washington should not remain at Mount Vernon while Congress is in recess. It will be good for his own health.
